Class TrampolineWorks

  • java.lang.Object
    • TrampolineWorks

  • public class TrampolineWorks
extends java.lang.Object
    A simple example to show that our Trampoline does what it should. The existence of this program is not meant to be a proof, but a demonstration. This could/should be turned into a test.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      TrampolineWorks()

    • Constructor Detail

      • TrampolineWorks

        public TrampolineWorks()

    • Method Detail

      • fac

        public static java.math.BigInteger fac(java.math.BigInteger x,
                                       java.math.BigInteger acc)
        This is a typical factorial function. It uses BigInteger because we are interested in the stack complexity, not performance. This will overflow the stack if called with a large number. e.g. fac(new BigInteger("10000000"), BigInteger.ONE);

      • facT

        public static me.elrod.pureio.Trampoline<java.math.BigInteger> facT(java.math.BigInteger x,
                                                                    java.math.BigInteger acc)
        This is a trampolined version of the above factorial function. It demonstrates that our trampoline does as we expect. While calling it with a huge number takes a considerable amount of time to yield a result, it never overflows the stack.

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] a)
